title: How to Make Beetroot Juice

steps.headline: Use a sharp, serrated or chef’s knife to trim the ends off the beets.
steps.description: Cut the greens off the top of the beetroot and trim about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) from the root end of the beet. Save the beet greens and stems for other purposes (like stews or stir fries) if you like. You can technically juice the top greens with beetroot, but it's more common to leave it out. If you do choose to include the greens, however, rinse them under cool running water and chop them into lengths measuring 2 inches (5.1 cm) or smaller. Juice them alongside the prepared beetroot.

steps.headline: Rinse the beetroots under cool running water.
steps.description: Rinsing the beets is necessary to clean off any dirt, debris, or germs. Use a vegetable brush to scrub off any dirt you cannot scrape away with your fingers. Tip: Beetroot skin contains plenty of nutrients, so if it's relatively thin, you should clean the skin and leave it intact for the juice. On the other hand, if the skin seems notably tough or dirty, you can peel the beetroot using a vegetable peeler or paring knife before moving onto the next step.

steps.headline: Use a sharp knife to cut the beets into quarters.
steps.description: First, cut each beetroot in half, then cut each chunk in half again to make 4 chunks total. You can cut them up a little more if you’re using a small or low-powered juicer. If the pieces are too large for the appliance, it could burn out the motor.

steps.headline: Set up your juicer’s collection and pulp containers.
steps.description: Place the collection pitcher beneath the pour spout of the juicer and attach the pulp container onto the base of the juicer (if applicable). Refer to your juicer’s instruction manual to see exactly how to set it up. If you have a model that does not come with its own collection pitcher, place a clean bowl or large glass beneath the spout. If your juicer doesn’t include an internal mesh strainer, place a small mesh strainer over the top of the collection cup or pitcher. If your model has a plunger to push fruits or vegetables into the chute, wash it with dish soap and water beforehand.

steps.headline: Feed the chunks through the juicer.
steps.description: Place one chunk of beetroot into the feed chute. Use the appliance's plunger to gently push the beetroot through the machine. Don’t add any more chunks until you see juice come out through the spout and pulp coming out of the pulp chute—that way, you won’t jam up the juicer. Beetroots are very hard, so it may take some time for the motor to process them. Don’t force the chunk through too quickly or firmly because doing so might burn out the motor.

steps.headline: Pour the collected beetroot juice into a serving glass.
steps.description: Enjoy the juice at room temperature or chill it for 30 minutes in the refrigerator if you like. Beetroot can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 2 days. For the freshest taste, enjoy the juice the same day that you make it.

methods.name: Making Beetroot Juice in a Blender

steps.headline: Place ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of water and 4 prepared beets into a blender.
steps.description: Place the quartered beetroot chunks and water in a high-powered blender. Depending on the size and power of your appliance, you might need to cut the quartered beets into smaller chunks. Since beetroots are hard, most blenders will have difficulty processing them dry. Adding a splash of water will help the blades cut through the beets easier at the beginning of the process.

steps.headline: Blend the beets and water at high speed.
steps.description: Puree the beetroots with the water on high speed until you no longer notice any large pieces of beetroot. There will still be lots of pulp, but try not to leave any chunks larger than a pencil eraser. If you want to toss in any spices, like fresh mint leaf, do so toward the end of the blending cycle. Dip a fork into the mixture to make sure most of the larger chunks are broken down. If they’re not, blend the beets for 30 seconds and check again.

steps.headline: Cut two 24 inches (61 cm) long pieces of cheesecloth and place it in a bowl.
steps.description: Stack the two pieces of cheesecloth on top of one another, then fold them in half to create four layers. Place the layered cheesecloth along the inside of a large bowl. If you don’t have cheesecloth, you can also balance a fine-mesh strainer over the mouth of a large bowl. Beet juice will stain your skin for a day or two, so put on some food-grade rubber or plastic gloves if you don’t want to have pink hands!

steps.headline: Pour the contents of the blender into the cheesecloth.
steps.description: Carefully pour the mixture into the center of the cheesecloth. Go slowly to ensure that all the pulp stays near the center. Place a strainer over the edge of the edge of the bowl to hold the cheesecloth in place, if necessary. Use a spoon to scrape all of the pulp out of the blender—do not use your fingers!

steps.headline: Squeeze the juice out of the cheesecloth.
steps.description: Gather the edges of the cloth together over the pulp, twist the opening closed, and squeeze down on the bundle to force the juice through the cloth and into the bowl. If you use a fine-mesh strainer, use a rubber spatula to press down on the pulp to extract as much juice as possible.

steps.headline: Enjoy the beetroot juice immediately or chill it in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Discard the pulp and pour the beetroot juice into a serving glass. Enjoy it immediately or drink it after the juice has chilled in your refrigerator for 30 minutes. You can refrigerate beetroot juice in an airtight container or bottle for up to 2 days, but it tastes better fresh.

steps.headline: Make a sweet and zesty juice by adding ginger, apple, and carrots.
steps.description: Ginger has a slightly spicy flavor, so use more or less to suit your tastes—a 1 inch (2.5 cm) piece packs a lot of flavor! Stir in a few fresh basil leaves for a rounded, earth-sweet taste. Peel the apple, remove the core, and cut it into quarters before feeding it through the juicer. Peel the carrots with a vegetable peeler, wash them, and chop them into 2 inches (5.1 cm) chunks before juicing.

steps.headline: Add pineapple and cucumber for a tropical tasting juice.
steps.description: Feed ½ of a whole cucumber, 1 cup (240 mL) of pineapple chunks, and the beetroot chunks into your juicer before stirring in ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of pineapple juice. You can drink the juice right away or chill it in the refrigerator for 30 minutes. Try stirring in a few fresh mint leaves for a bright, refreshing taste. You can also substitute the ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of pineapple juice with coconut water if you prefer a coconutty taste (and less sugar).

steps.headline: Create healthy pink lemonade by adding white grape juice and lemon.
steps.description: Squeeze in ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of lemon juice, 2 cups (470 mL) of 100% white grape juice, and 3 cups (710 mL) of water for each juiced beet to make a sweet, refreshing summer drink. Serve it with frozen berries in the bottom for a sweeter finish.

steps.headline: Add beet juice to your superfood smoothies.
steps.description: Use a blender to whip up an antioxidant-rich smoothie with ½ of an avocado, ⁄4 cup (180 mL) of frozen blueberries, 1 cup (240 mL) of spinach, and ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of milk. Add ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of fresh beetroot juice at the very end of the blending process. Blend in 1 tablespoon (3.0  tsp) of chia seeds for a healthy dose of omega 3 fatty acids.

steps.headline: Make a refreshing summer sipper with watermelon, lemon, and beetroot.
steps.description: Watermelon and lemon are the perfect accompaniment to beetroot juice to sweeten it up and add a little acidity. First, juice 2 medium-sized beets, 3 cups (710 mL) to 4 cups (950 mL) of seedless watermelon chunks and then squeeze in the juice of ½ of a lemon once you’re ready to enjoy it. This juice is best served chilled, so chill it in the refrigerator for 30 minutes or add couple scoops of ice. Make it a perfect poolside cocktail by adding 1.5 fluid ounces (44 mL) of tequila (blanco) or vodka.

steps.headline: Combine beetroot juice, ginger beer, and tequila for a zesty cocktail.
steps.description: Use 1 fluid ounce (30 mL) of beetroot juice, 3 fluid ounces (89 mL) of ginger beer, the juice of ½ of a lime, and 1.5 fluid ounces (44 mL) of tequila blanco. After juicing the beetroot, simply add all the ingredients to a shaker with 1 cup (240 mL) of ice and shake it. Place a wheel of lime on the rim of the serving glass for a festive look. Substitute mezcal in place of tequila for a sweeter, richer taste.

tyn_section: Cheesecloth, jelly bag, or fine-mesh strainer
